defs.docs:
A flexible and easy-to-use logger that writes logs to stderr and/or to files
 or other output streams.

attributes.value: / A flexible and easy-to-use logger that writes logs to stderr and/or to files
/ To read the log specification from an environment variable and get the log written to `stderr`,
/ * The builder [`Logger`] for a full description of all configuration options,
/ * module [`code_examples`] for various concrete examples of `flexi_logger` initialization
/ * the module [`writers`] for the usage of additional log writers,
/ * and [the README](https://crates.io/crates/flexi_logger) for how to get started.
/ There are configuration options to e.g.
/ * decide whether you want to write your logs to stderr or to a file,
/ * configure the path and the filenames of the log files,
/ * specify the line format for the log lines,
/ * apply a stateful filter before log lines are really written,
/ * define additional log output streams, e.g for alert or security messages,
/ * support changing the log specification while the program is running,
/ for specifying which logs should really be written (but is more graceful with the syntax,
/ By default, i.e. if feature `colors` is not switched off, the log lines that appear on your
/ terminal are coloured. In case the chosen colors don't fit to your terminal's color theme,
/ you can adapt the colors to improve readability.
/ for a description how this can be done.

attributes.value: / Is used to ensure that a log record that is sent to multiple outputs
/ (in maybe different formats) always uses the same timestamp.

The provided path should describe a log file.

 If necessary, parent folders will be created.

attributes.value: / The provided path should describe a log file.
/ If it exists, it must be a file, not a folder.
/ If necessary, parent folders will be created.
/ [`FlexiLoggerError::OutputBadFile`] if the given path exists and is a folder.
/ Panics if the basename of the given path has no filename

defs.name: FlexiLoggerError
defs.value:
pub enum FlexiLoggerError {
    Reset,
    OutputBadDirectory,
    OutputBadFile,
    OutputCleanupThread(std::io::Error),
    OutputIo(std::io::Error),
    LevelFilter(String),
    Parse(String, LogSpecification),
    Log(log::SetLoggerError),
    Poison,
    Palette(std::num::ParseIntError),
}
defs.docs: Describes errors in the initialization of `flexi_logger`.

attributes.value: / Describes errors in the initialization of `flexi_logger`.

defs.name: Custom
defs.docs:
Chooses between the first format function (which is supposed to be uncolored)
 and the second (which is supposed to be colored).

attributes.value: / Chooses between the first format function (which is supposed to be uncolored)
/ and the second (which is supposed to be colored).
/ Allows providing own format functions, with freely choosable coloring technique,
/ _and_ making use of the tty detection.

defs.name: AdaptiveFormat
defs.value:
pub enum AdaptiveFormat {
    Default,
    Detailed,
    Opt,
    WithThread,
    Custom(FormatFunction, FormatFunction),
}
defs.docs:
Can be used in
 [`Logger::adaptive_format_for_stderr`](crate::Logger::adaptive_format_for_stderr) and
 [`Logger::adaptive_format_for_stdout`](crate::Logger::adaptive_format_for_stdout)
 to use coloring only if the output goes to a tty.

attributes.value: / to use coloring only if the output goes to a tty.
/ This is helpful if the output is sometimes piped into other programs, which usually
/ do not expect color control byte sequences.

defs.name: FormatFunction
defs.value:
fn(write: &mut dyn std::io::Write, now: &mut DeferredNow, record: &Record)
    -> Result<(), std::io::Error>
defs.docs: Function type for format functions.

attributes.value: / If you want to write the log lines in your own format,
/ implement a function with this signature and provide it to one of the methods
/ Check out the code of the provided [format functions](index.html#functions)
/ if you want to start with a template.
/ - `now`: the timestamp that you should use if you want a timestamp to appear in the log line
/ - `record`: the log line's content and metadata, as provided by the log crate's macros.

defs.name: LogSpecification
defs.docs:
Immutable struct that defines which loglines are to be written,
 based on the module, the log level, and the text.

attributes.value: / Immutable struct that defines which loglines are to be written,
/ based on the module, the log level, and the text.
/ but we are a bit more tolerant with spaces. Its functionality can be
/   * `"info"`: all logs with info, warn, or error level are written
/   * `"crate1"`: all logs of this crate are written, but nothing else
/   * `"warn, crate2::mod_a=debug, mod_x::mod_y=trace"`: all crates log warnings and errors,
/     `mod_a` additionally debug messages, and `mod_x::mod_y` is fully traced
/ * If you just specify the module, without `log_level`, all levels will be traced for this
/ * If you just specify a log level, this will be applied as default to all modules without
/   (You see that for modules named error, warn, info, debug or trace,
/   it is necessary to specify their loglevel explicitly).
/ * The module names are compared as Strings, with the side effect that a specified module filter
/ affects all modules whose name starts with this String.
/ The optional text filter is applied for all modules.
/ Note that external module names are to be specified like in ```"extern crate ..."```, i.e.,
/ for crates with a dash in their name this means: the dash is to be replaced with
/ for an explanation of the different naming conventions in Cargo (packages allow hyphen) and
/ rustc (extern crate does not allow hyphens).

defs.name: do_not_log
defs.docs: Log is processed, including duplication, but not written to any destination.

attributes.value: / Log is processed, including duplication, but not written to any destination.
/ This can be useful e.g. for running application tests with all log-levels active and still
/ avoiding tons of log files etc.
/ Such tests ensure that the log calls which are normally not active
/ will not cause undesired side-effects when activated
/ (note that the log macros may prevent arguments of inactive log-calls from being evaluated).
/ Or, if you want to get logs both to stdout and stderr, but nowhere else,
/ then use this option and combine it with

Makes the logger print an info message to stdout with the name of the logfile
 when a logfile is opened for writing.

defs.name: format
defs.docs:
Makes the logger use the provided format function for all messages
 that are written to files, stderr, stdout, or to an additional writer.

attributes.value: / Makes the logger use the provided format function for all messages
/ that are written to files, stderr, stdout, or to an additional writer.
/ You can either choose one of the provided log-line formatters,
/ or you create and use your own format function with the signature
/ By default, [`default_format`] is used for output to files and to custom writers,
/ and [`AdaptiveFormat::Default`] is used for output to `stderr` and `stdout`.
/ If the feature `colors` is switched off, [`default_format`] is used for all outputs.

defs.name: set_palette
defs.docs:
Sets the color palette for function [`style`](crate::style), which is used in the
 provided coloring format functions.

attributes.value: / Sets the color palette for function [`style`](crate::style), which is used in the
/ The palette given here overrides the default palette.
/ The palette is specified in form of a String that contains a semicolon-separated list
/ The first five values denote the fixed color that is
/ The String `"196;208;-;7;8"` describes the default palette, where color 196 is
/ used for error messages, and so on. The `-` means that no coloring is done,
/ i.e., with `"-;-;-;-;-"` all coloring is switched off.
/ Prefixing a number with 'b' makes the output being written in bold.
/ The String `"b1;3;2;4;6"` e.g. describes the palette used by `env_logger`.
/ The palette can further be overridden at runtime by setting the environment variable
/ `FLEXI_LOGGER_PALETTE` to a palette String. This allows adapting the used text colors to
/ For your convenience, if you want to specify your own palette,
/ you can produce a colored list with all 255 colors with `cargo run --example colors`.

defs.name: rotate
defs.value: pub fn rotate(Self, Criterion, Naming, Cleanup) -> Self
defs.docs:
Prevent indefinite growth of the log file by applying file rotation
 and a clean-up strategy for older log files.

attributes.value: / Prevent indefinite growth of the log file by applying file rotation
/ and a clean-up strategy for older log files.
/ By default, the log file is fixed while your program is running and will grow indefinitely.
/ With this option being used, when the log file reaches the specified criterion,
/ the file will be closed and a new file will be opened.
/ Note that also the filename pattern changes:
/ - by default, no timestamp is added to the filename if rotation is used
/ - the logs are always written to a file with infix `_rCURRENT`
/ - when the rotation criterion is fulfilled, it is closed and renamed to a file
/   and then the logging continues again to the (fresh) file with infix `_rCURRENT`.
/ After some logging with your program `my_prog` and rotation with `Naming::Numbers`,
/ `criterion` defines *when* the log file should be rotated, based on its size or age.
/ `naming` defines the naming convention for the rotated log files.
/ `cleanup` defines the strategy for dealing with older files.

defs.name: cleanup_in_background_thread
defs.docs:
When [`Logger::rotate`] is used with some [`Cleanup`] variant other than [`Cleanup::Never`],
 then this method can be used to define
 if the cleanup activities (finding files, deleting files, evtl compressing files) are
 delegated to a background thread (which is the default,
 to minimize the blocking impact to your application caused by IO operations),
 or whether they are done synchronously in the current log-call.

attributes.value: / When [`Logger::rotate`] is used with some [`Cleanup`] variant other than [`Cleanup::Never`],
/ then this method can be used to define
/ if the cleanup activities (finding files, deleting files, evtl compressing files) are
/ delegated to a background thread (which is the default,
/ to minimize the blocking impact to your application caused by IO operations),
/ or whether they are done synchronously in the current log-call.
/ If you call this method with `use_background_thread = false`,

defs.name: append
defs.docs:
Makes the logger append to the specified output file, if it exists already;
 by default, the file would be truncated.

attributes.value: / Makes the logger append to the specified output file, if it exists already;
/ by default, the file would be truncated.
/ This option only has an effect if logs are written to files, but
/ it will hardly make an effect if [`FileSpec::suppress_timestamp`] is not used.

defs.name: create_symlink
defs.value: pub fn create_symlink<P: Into<PathBuf>>(Self, P) -> Self
defs.docs:
The specified path will be used on linux systems to create a symbolic link
 to the current log file.

attributes.value: / The specified path will be used on linux systems to create a symbolic link
/ This option has no effect on filesystems where symlinks are not supported,
/ and it only has an effect if logs are written to files.
/ You can use the symbolic link to follow the log output with `tail`,
/ even if the log files are rotated.

defs.name: o_print_message
defs.docs:
With true, makes the logger print an info message to stdout, each time
 when a new file is used for log-output.

attributes.value: / With true, makes the logger print an info message to stdout, each time

defs.name: o_rotate
defs.value: pub fn o_rotate(Self, Option<(Criterion, Naming, Cleanup)>) -> Self
defs.docs:
By default, and with None, the log file will grow indefinitely.
 If a `rotate_config` is set, when the log file reaches or exceeds the specified size,
 the file will be closed and a new file will be opened.
 Also the filename pattern changes: instead of the timestamp, a serial number
 is included into the filename.

attributes.value: / By default, and with None, the log file will grow indefinitely.
/ If a `rotate_config` is set, when the log file reaches or exceeds the specified size,
/ the file will be closed and a new file will be opened.
/ Also the filename pattern changes: instead of the timestamp, a serial number
/ The size is given in bytes, e.g. `o_rotate_over_size(Some(1_000))` will rotate
/ files once they reach a size of 1 kB.
/ The cleanup strategy allows delimiting the used space on disk.

defs.name: o_append
defs.docs: This option only has an effect if `log_to_file` is set to true.

attributes.value: / This option only has an effect if `log_to_file` is set to true.
/ If append is set to true, makes the logger append to the specified output file, if it exists.
/ By default, or with false, the file would be truncated.
/ This option will hardly make an effect if `suppress_timestamp()` is not used.

defs.name: o_create_symlink
defs.value:
pub fn o_create_symlink>(Self, Option

) -> Self
defs.docs: This option only has an effect if `log_to_file` is set to true.

attributes.value: / This option only has an effect if `log_to_file` is set to true.
/ If a String is specified, it will be used on linux systems to create in the current folder
/ a symbolic link with this name to the current log file.

defs.name: start
defs.docs: Consumes the Logger object and initializes `flexi_logger`.

attributes.value: / Consumes the Logger object and initializes `flexi_logger`.
/ **Keep the [`LoggerHandle`] alive up to the very end of your program!**
/ Dropping the [`LoggerHandle`] flushes and shuts down [`FileLogWriter`]s
/ and other [`LogWriter`]s, and then may prevent further logging!
/ This should happen immediately before the program terminates, but not earlier.
/ The [`LoggerHandle`] also allows updating the log specification programmatically,
/ e.g. to intensify logging for (buggy) parts of a (test) program, etc.
/     // ... do all your work and join back all threads whose logs you want to see ...

defs.name: build
defs.value:
pub fn build(Self)
-> Result<(Box<dyn log::Log>, LoggerHandle), FlexiLoggerError>
defs.docs:
Builds a boxed logger and a `LoggerHandle` for it,
 but does not initialize the global logger.

attributes.value: / Builds a boxed logger and a `LoggerHandle` for it,
/ but does not initialize the global logger.
/ The returned boxed logger implements the [`Log`](log::Log) trait
/ and can be installed manually or nested within another logger.
/ **Keep the [`LoggerHandle`] alive up to the very end of your program!**

defs.name: LoggerHandle
defs.docs: Shuts down the logger when dropped, and allows reconfiguring the logger programmatically.

attributes.value: / Shuts down the logger when dropped, and allows reconfiguring the logger programmatically.
/ A `LoggerHandle` is returned from `Logger::start()` and from `Logger::start_with_specfile()`.
/ When the logger handle is dropped, then it shuts down the Logger!
/ This matters if you use one of `Logger::log_to_file`, `Logger::log_to_writer`, or
/ `Logger::log_to_file_and_writer`. It is then important to keep the logger handle alive
/ until the very end of your program!
/ `LoggerHandle` offers methods to modify the log specification programmatically,
/ to flush() the logger explicitly, and even to reconfigure the used `FileLogWriter` --
/ Since dropping the `LoggerHandle` has no effect if you use
/ you can then safely ignore the return value of `Logger::start()`:
/ When logging to a file or another writer, keep the `LoggerHandle` alive until the program ends:
/ You can use the logger handle to permanently exchange the log specification programmatically,
/ However, when debugging, you often want to modify the log spec only temporarily, for
/ one or few method calls only; this is easier done with the following method, because
/ it allows switching back to the previous spec:
/ // Continue with the log spec you had before.

/ - you use some [`Cleanup`](crate::Cleanup) strategy with compression:

/   which could leave unexpected files in the filesystem
/ - you use your own writer(s), and they need to clean up resources

defs.name: Age
defs.docs: Rotate the log file when it has become older than the specified age.

attributes.value: / Rotate the log file when it has become older than the specified age.
/ with `Criterion::Age` works OK, but not perfectly correct on Windows or Linux
/ Applying the age criterion works fine while your program is running.
/ Ideally, we should also apply it to the rCURRENT file when the program is restarted
/ Unfortunately, this does not work on Windows, and it does not work on linux,
/ To minimize the impact on age-based file-rotation,
/ `flexi_logger` uses on Windows and linux its initialization time
/ rather than the real file property
/ as the created_at-info of an rCURRENT file that already exists, and the
/ current timestamp when file rotation happens during further execution.
/ Consequently, a left-over rCURRENT file from a previous program run will look newer
/ than it is, and will be used longer than it should be.
/ For compatibility with DOS (sic!), Windows magically transfers the created_at-info
/ of a file that is deleted (or renamed) to its successor,
/ when the recreation happens within some seconds [\[1\]](#ref-1).
/ If the file property were used by `flexi_logger`,
/ the rCURRENT file would always appear to be as old as the
/ first one that ever was created - rotation by time would completely fail.
/ `std::fs::metadata.created()` returns `Err`, because linux does not maintain a

defs.name: Naming
defs.docs: The naming convention for rotated log files.

attributes.value: / The naming convention for rotated log files.
/ With file rotation, the logs are written to a file with infix `_rCURRENT`.
/ When rotation happens, the CURRENT log file will be renamed to a file with
/ another infix of the form `"_r..."`. `Naming` defines which other infix will be used.

defs.name: Never
defs.docs: Older log files are not touched - they remain for ever.

attributes.value: / Older log files are not touched - they remain for ever.

defs.name: KeepLogFiles
defs.docs:
The specified number of rotated log files are kept.
 Older files are deleted, if necessary.

attributes.value: / The specified number of rotated log files are kept.
/ Older files are deleted, if necessary.

defs.name: Cleanup
defs.docs: Defines the strategy for handling older log files.

attributes.value: / Defines the strategy for handling older log files.
/ Note that if you use a strategy other than `Cleanup::Never`, then the cleanup work is
/ by default done in an extra thread, to minimize the impact on the program.
/ to avoid interrupting a currently active cleanup when your program terminates.
/ if you want to control whether this extra thread is created and used.

attributes.value: / Default flush interval (1s), when flushing is used.

defs.name: Direct
defs.docs: Do not buffer (default).

attributes.value: / Every log line is directly written to the output, without buffering.
/ This allows seeing new log lines in real time, and does not need additional threads.

defs.docs:
Same as `BufferAndFlushWith` with default capacity ([`DEFAULT_BUFFER_CAPACITY`])
 and default interval ([`DEFAULT_FLUSH_INTERVAL`]).

defs.docs: Buffer and flush with given buffer capacity and flush interval.

attributes.value: / Buffer and flush with given buffer capacity and flush interval.

defs.name: BufferDontFlushWith
defs.docs: Buffer with given buffer capacity, but don't flush.

attributes.value: / Buffer with given buffer capacity, but don't flush.
/ This might be handy if you want to minimize I/O effort and don't want to create
/ the extra thread for flushing and don't care if log lines appear with delay.

defs.name: WriteMode
defs.value:
pub enum WriteMode {
    Direct,
    BufferAndFlush,
    BufferAndFlushWith(usize, Duration),
    BufferDontFlush,
    BufferDontFlushWith(usize),
}
defs.docs:
Describes whether the log output should be written synchronously or asynchronously,
 and if and how I/O should be buffered and flushed.

attributes.value: / Describes whether the log output should be written synchronously or asynchronously,
/ and if and how I/O should be buffered and flushed.
/ Buffering reduces the program's I/O overhead, and thus increases overall performance,
/ which can become relevant if logging is used heavily.
/ On the other hand, if logging is used with low frequency,
/ buffering can defer the appearance of log lines significantly,
/ so regular flushing is usually advisable with buffering.
/ **Note** that for all options except `Direct` you should keep the
/ up to the very end of your program to ensure that all buffered log lines are flushed out
/ (which happens automatically when the [`LoggerHandle`](struct.LoggerHandle.html) is dropped)
/ **Note** further that flushing uses an extra thread (with minimal stack).
/ The console is a slow output device (at least on Windows).
/ With `WriteMode::Async` it can happen that in phases with vast log output
/ the log lines appear significantly later than they were written.
/ Also, a final printing phase is possible at the end of the program when the logger handle
/ is dropped (and all output is flushed automatically).
/ `WriteMode::Direct` (i.e. without buffering) is the slowest option with all output devices,
/ showing that buffered I/O pays off. But it takes slightly more resources, especially
/ if you do not suppress flushing.
/ Using `log_to_stdout()` and then redirecting the output to a file makes things faster,
/ but is still significantly slower than writing to files directly.

defs.name: code_examples
defs.docs: Here are some examples for the `flexi_logger` initialization.

attributes.value: / Here are some examples for the `flexi_logger` initialization.
/ - [Influence the location and name of the log file](#influence-the-location-and-name-of-the-log-file)
/ - [Specify the format for the log lines explicitly](#specify-the-format-for-the-log-lines-explicitly)
/ - [Use a fixed log file, and truncate or append the file on each program start](#use-a-fixed-log-file-and-truncate-or-append-the-file-on-each-program-start)
/ - [Reconfigure the log specification dynamically by editing a spec-file](#reconfigure-the-log-specification-dynamically-by-editing-a-spec-file)
/ ## Start minimal: Write logs to stderr
/ Choose one of three options to specify which log output you want to see, and call start:
/   provide the log specification in the environment variable `RUST_LOG`:
/   Note that if `RUST_LOG` is not set, or if its value cannot be interpreted, nothing is logged.
/ After that, you just use the log-macros from the log crate.
/ By default, logs are written to `stderr`.
/ you can send the logs to other destinations, or write them not at all.
/ When writing to files or to a writer,
/ you sometimes want to see some parts of the log additionally on the terminal;
/ which duplicate log messages to the terminal.
/     .duplicate_to_stderr(Duplicate::Warn)     // print warnings and errors also to the console
/ By default, every log line is directly written to the output, without buffering.
/ This allows seeing new log lines in real time.
/ you have some options to change this behavior, e.g.
/   you can reduce the program's I/O overhead and thus increase overall performance,
/   which can be relevant if logging is used heavily.
/   In addition, to keep a short maximum wait time
/   until a log line is visible in the output channel,
/   an extra thread is created that flushes the buffers regularly.
/   logs are sent from your application threads through an unbounded channel
/   to an output thread, which does the output (and the rotation and the cleanup, if applicable).
/   Additionally the output is buffered, and a bounded message pool is used to reduce allocations,
/   and flushing is used to avoid long delays.
/   If duplication is used, the messages to `stdout` or `stderr` are written synchronously.
/ up to the very end of your program,
/ because it will, in its Drop implementation, flush all writers
/ to ensure that all buffered log lines are flushed before the program terminates,
/ and then it calls their shutdown method.
/ ## Influence the location and name of the log file
/ By default, the log files are created in the current directory (where the program was started).
/ you can specify a concrete folder in which the files should be created.
/ you can add a discriminating infix to the log file name.
/ you can change the suffix that is used for the log files.
/ When writing to files, especially when they are in a distant folder, you may want to let the
/ user know where the log file is.
/ prints an info to `stdout` to which file the log is written.
/ creates (on unix-systems only) a symbolic link at the specified path that points to the log file.
/             .discriminant("Sample4711A")     // use infix in log file name
/     .create_symlink("current_run")           // create a symbolic link to the current log file
/ This example will print a message like
/ and, on unix, create a symbolic link called `current_run`.
/ ## Specify the format for the log lines explicitly
/ you set the format for all used output channels of `flexi_logger`.
/ `flexi_logger` provides a couple of format functions, and you can also create and use your own,
/ e.g. by copying and modifying one of the provided format functions.
/ Depending on the configuration, `flexi_logger` can write logs to multiple channels
/ at the same time. You can control the format for each output channel individually, using
/  As argument for these functions you can use one of the provided non-coloring format functions
/ or one of their coloring pendants
/ You can use coloring for `stdout` and/or `stderr`
/ * are used when the output goes to a tty,
/ * are suppressed when you e.g. pipe the output to some other program.
/ by providing one of the variants of [`AdaptiveFormat`](crate::AdaptiveFormat) to the respective
/ `flexi_logger` initializes by default equivalently to this:
/ # use log::{debug, error, info, trace, warn};
/ # Logger::try_with_str("info")?      // Write all error, warn, and info messages
/ # debug!("This is a debug message - you must not see it!");
/ # trace!("This is a trace message - you must not see it!");
/ ## Use a fixed log file, and truncate or append the file on each program start
/ `flexi_logger` uses by default files with a timestamp in the name, like
/ `foo_2020-11-16_08-37-44.log` (for a program called `foo`), which are quite unique for each
/ you get a simple fixed filename, like `foo.log`.
/ In that case, a restart of the program will truncate an existing log file.
/ to append the logs of each new run to the existing file.
/ # use log::{debug, error, info, trace, warn};
/ Logger::try_with_str("info")? // Write all error, warn, and info messages
/     // use a simple filename without a timestamp
/     // do not truncate the log file when the program is restarted
/ # debug!("This is a debug message - you must not see it!");
/ # trace!("This is a trace message - you must not see it!");
/ With rotation, the logs are always written to a file
/ takes three enum arguments that define its behavior:
/      when the clock switches to a new day, hour, minute, or second
/      when the current log file exceeds the specified limit
/      when either of the two limits is reached
/   and a fresh `rCURRENT` file is created.
/     the number of log files that should be retained;
/     if there are more, the older ones are getting deleted
/     the number of log files that should be
/     retained, and these are being compressed additionally
/     you specify the number of log files that should be
/     retained as is, and an additional number that are being compressed
/   - with [`Cleanup::Never`](crate::Cleanup::Never) no cleanup is done, all files are retained.
/ # use flexi_logger::{Age, Cleanup, Criterion, FileSpec, Logger, Naming};
/ # use log::{debug, error, info, trace, warn};
/ Logger::try_with_str("info")?      // Write all error, warn, and info messages
/     .rotate(                      // If the program runs long enough,
/         Criterion::Age(Age::Day), // - create a new file every day
/         Naming::Timestamps,       // - let the rotated files have a timestamp in their name
/         Cleanup::KeepLogFiles(7), // - keep at most 7 log files
/ #   debug!("This is a debug message - you must not see it!");
/ #   trace!("This is a trace message - you must not see it!");
/ This can be especially handy in debugging situations where you want to see
/ log output only for a short instant.
/ and modify the effective log specification from within your code:
/ // ... continue with the log spec you had before.
/ ## Reconfigure the log specification dynamically by editing a spec-file
/ If you start `flexi_logger` with a specfile,
/ then you can change the log specification dynamically, *while your program is running*,
/ by editing the specfile. This can be a great help e.g. if you want to get detailed log output
/ for _some_ requests to a long running server.
/ When using `Logger::log_to_file()`, you can change most of the properties of the
/ embedded `FileLogWriter` while the program is running using
/ Obtain the [`LoggerHandle`](crate::LoggerHandle) when the program is started
/ use flexi_logger::{writers::FileLogWriter, Cleanup, Criterion, FileSpec, Naming};
/ and modify the file log writer later:
/ # use flexi_logger::{writers::FileLogWriter, Cleanup, Criterion, FileSpec, Naming};
/ For the sake of completeness, we refer here to some more configuration methods.
/ See their documentation for more details.

defs.name: writers
defs.docs:
Contains the trait [`LogWriter`] for extending `flexi_logger`
 with additional log writers,
 and two concrete implementations
 for writing to files ([`FileLogWriter`])
 or to the syslog ([`SyslogWriter`]).
 You can also use your own implementations of [`LogWriter`].

attributes.value: / You can also use your own implementations of [`LogWriter`].
/ Such log writers can be used in two ways:
/ * You can influence to which output stream normal log messages will be written,
/   i.e. those from normal log macro calls without explicit target specification.
/   By default, the logs are sent to stderr. With one of the methods
/   you can specify a different log target. See there for more details.
/   Normal log calls will only be written to the chosen output channel if they match the current
/ * You can register additional log writers under a target name with
/   [`Logger::add_writer()`](crate::Logger::add_writer), and address these log writers by
/   specifying the target name in calls to the
/   A log call with a target value that has the form `{Name1,Name2,...}`, i.e.,
/   a comma-separated list of target names, within braces, is not sent to the default logger,
/   but to the loggers specified explicitly in the list.
/   In such a list you can again specify the default logger with the target name `_Default`.
/   These log calls will not be affected by the value of `flexi_logger`'s log specification;
/   they will always be written, as you might want it for alerts or auditing.
/   In the following example we define an alert writer, and a macro to facilitate using it
/   (and avoid using the explicit target specification in the macro call), and
/   // Configure a FileLogWriter for alert messages
/   // Define a macro for writing messages to the alert log and to the normal log
/       // Explicitly send logs to different loggers
/       error!(target : "{Alert,_Default}", "This is an alert and log message");
/       alert_error!("This is another alert and log message");
/       // Standard log macros write only to the normal log
/       error!("This is a normal error message");
/       debug!("This is a debug message - you will not see it");
/       trace!("This is a trace message - you will not see it");

defs.name: cleanup_in_background_thread
defs.docs:
Influences how the cleanup activities
 (finding files, deleting files, optionally compressing files) are done
 when rotation is used with some [`Cleanup`] variant.

attributes.value: / (finding files, deleting files, optionally compressing files) are done
/ when rotation is used with some [`Cleanup`] variant.
/ the cleanup activities are done by default in a dedicated background thread, to
/ minimize the blocking impact on your application.
/ You can avoid this extra thread by calling this method with
/ `use_background_thread = false`; the cleanup is then done synchronously
/ by the thread that is currently logging and - by chance - causing a file rotation.
/ the cleanup activities are always done by the same background thread
/ that also does the file I/O, this method then has no effect.

defs.name: rotate
defs.value: pub fn rotate(Self, Criterion, Naming, Cleanup) -> Self
defs.docs: Use rotation to prevent indefinite growth of log files.

attributes.value: / Use rotation to prevent indefinite growth of log files.
/ By default, the log file is fixed while your program is running and will grow indefinitely.
/ With this option being used, when the log file reaches the specified criterion,
/ the file will be closed and a new file will be opened.
/ Note that also the filename pattern changes:
/ - by default, no timestamp is added to the filename
/ - the logs are always written to a file with infix `_rCURRENT`
/ - when the rotation criterion is fulfilled, it is closed and renamed to a file
/   and then the logging continues again to the (fresh) file with infix `_rCURRENT`.
/ After some logging with your program `my_prog` and rotation with `Naming::Numbers`,
/ The cleanup parameter allows defining the strategy for dealing with older files.

defs.name: o_rotate
defs.value: pub fn o_rotate(Self, Option<(Criterion, Naming, Cleanup)>) -> Self
defs.docs:
By default, and with None, the log file will grow indefinitely.
 If a `rotate_config` is set, when the log file reaches or exceeds the specified size,
 the file will be closed and a new file will be opened.
 Also the filename pattern changes: instead of the timestamp, a serial number
 is included into the filename.

attributes.value: / By default, and with None, the log file will grow indefinitely.
/ If a `rotate_config` is set, when the log file reaches or exceeds the specified size,
/ the file will be closed and a new file will be opened.
/ Also the filename pattern changes: instead of the timestamp, a serial number
/ The size is given in bytes, e.g. `o_rotate_over_size(Some(1_000))` will rotate
/ files once they reach a size of 1 kB.
/ The cleanup strategy allows delimiting the used space on disk.

defs.name: o_append
defs.docs:
If append is set to true, makes the logger append to the given file, if it exists.
 By default, or with false, the file would be truncated.

attributes.value: / If append is set to true, makes the logger append to the given file, if it exists.
/ By default, or with false, the file would be truncated.

/ compares the written log with the expected lines,
/ and asserts that both are in sync.
/ This function is not meant for productive code, only for tests.

defs.name: error_info
defs.docs: Error codes of `flexi_logger`.

attributes.value: / The following error codes are used to indicate the reason of an error.
/ More details on them can be found here.
/ Writing the log line to the output failed.
/ [flexi_logger][ERRCODE::Write] writing log line failed, caused by Send
/ Possible reasons depend on the `WriteMode` and the output channel.
/ With an asynchronous `WriteMode`, the root cause can be that the logger handle that was returned
/ from the logger initialization was not assigned to a variable to keep it alive (see also
/ It is then dropped immediately, and in its `Drop` impl it cleans up all ressources,
/ including the asynchronous writer. So the next log output will fail with this error.
/ Explicit or automatic flushing of buffered log lines to the output failed.
/ [flexi_logger][ERRCODE::Flush] flushing primary writer failed, caused by Send
/ Possible reasons depend on the `WriteMode` and the output channel.
/ With an asynchronous `WriteMode`, the root cause can be that the logger handle that was returned
/ from the logger initialization was not assigned to a variable to keep it alive (see also
/ It is then dropped immediately, and in its `Drop` impl it cleans up all ressources,
/ including the asynchronous writer. So the next log output will fail with this error.
/ The chosen format function had produced an error.
/ If this happens with one of `flexi_logger`s provided format functions, please open an issue.
/ Log entries can be written by all threads of your program. Loggers thus must be thread-safe,
/ by keeping their mutable parts in `Mutex`es, `RwLocks`, etc. In case that a thread panics
/ while owning one of these locks, the lock is subsequently considered "poisoned".
/ Most likely the root cause for this is some panic! in a `Debug` or `Display` implementation
/ The `FileLogWriter` is not able to rotate the log file. The reason should be printed as well.
/ This error can only occur if you use `Logger::start_with_specfile`, where you specify a
/ log-specification-file that you can edit, while the program is running, to influence
/ which log lines it should write.
/ because rereading the log specification file failed, caused by ...
/ The log-specification-file you chose with `Logger::start_with_specfile` cannot be opened,
/ [flexi_logger][ERRCODE::LogSpecFile] error while watching the specfile, caused by ...
/ This error can only occur on linux systems, and when you use `Logger::create_symlink`, and
/ indicates an issue with creating or replacing the symbolic link to the log file.
/ The code uses in some log macro call the syntax to send the log line to a certain `LogWriter`,
/ but this log writer does not exist.
